page.title: 16The New Harbour Entrance
page.content: Thomas Delaval began his work on the new entrance in the Autumn of 1761. A cut was to be driven straight East from the river bend to the sea, a distance of 900 feet. The task was a formidable one for the way was through solid rock. After several months of hewing at the rock and making little headway, Delaval decided to use a German method of blasting with lime. This was a huge success and the new cut was ready in 1764. However, an error had been made in gauging the high water mark, which meant that the dock was too shallow for capacity loading. To save expense and delay, the cut was deepened in 1772, having a new depth of eleven to sixteen feet of water.
